questions.question: Which of the following can be done using PL/SQL?

options.why_false: While this is possible, it is not the only correct option listed. PL/SQL is capable of all the tasks mentioned.

options.text: Retrieve and modify data in Oracle database tables
options.why_false: This is a valid function of PL/SQL, but it is not the exclusive answer. 'All of these' is the correct choice.

options.text: Manage database tasks such as security
options.why_false: Database security management is possible, but other options are also correct.
PL/SQL can indeed create complex applications, but this is only one of its many capabilities listed.

options.text: All of these can be done

questions.question: Which of the following can be done using PL/SQL?

options.why_false: This is a valid use case, but not the only one in the list.

options.text: Develop Web applications using the Web Application Toolkit
options.why_false: This is possible (e.g., using PL/SQL Web Toolkit), but it is part of a broader set of capabilities.
Security management is a valid feature, but the question implies looking for the most inclusive answer.
Updating data is a core function, but 'All of these' covers the other valid options as well.

options.text: All of these can be done

questions.question: Comparing PL/SQL with other languages such as C and Java, which of the following statements is true?

options.text: PL/SQL is easier to learn and more efficient
PL/SQL is easier to learn and does not require an Oracle database or tool
options.why_false: PL/SQL is tightly integrated with Oracle and strictly requires an Oracle Database or a compatible tool to compile and execute.

options.text: PL/SQL is easier to learn but less efficient
options.why_false: PL/SQL is highly efficient for database operations because it runs inside the database server, minimizing network traffic.
PL/SQL is generally considered easier to learn for database developers because it abstracts memory management and system-level details found in C or Java.

questions.question: Using Oracle Application Express, you can create Web applications that include PL/SQL. True or False?

options.why_false: Oracle Application Express (APEX) is explicitly designed to build web apps using SQL and PL/SQL.

questions.question: Procedural constructs give you better control of your SQL statements and their execution. True or False?

options.why_false: Procedural constructs (loops, conditions) allow developers to control the flow of execution and logic around SQL statements, which SQL alone cannot do.

questions.question: In which three ways does PL/SQL extend the SQL programming language? (Choose all correct answers)

options.why_false: While 'compound' might sound technical, the standard definition of PL/SQL extensions highlights procedural, conditional, and iterative controls. Compound triggers exist, but 'compound constructs' is not the standard terminology for the core language extension.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?

options.text: You can embed PL/SQL statements within SQL code.
options.why_false: You generally call PL/SQL functions from SQL, but you do not embed raw PL/SQL blocks (like BEGIN...END) directly inside a standard SQL statement.

options.text: You can embed procedural constructs within SQL code.
options.why_false: Standard SQL does not support procedural constructs like loops or IF statements directly; they must be wrapped in PL/SQL blocks.

options.text: You can embed SQL statements within PL/SQL code.

options.why_false: One of the options (Embedding SQL in PL/SQL) is correct.

questions.question: PL/SQL is an Oracle proprietary, procedural, fourth-generation programming language. True or False?

options.why_false: PL/SQL is considered a Third-Generation Language (3GL) extension to SQL (which is 4GL). It adds procedural logic (3GL traits) to the declarative SQL.

questions.question: SQL is a common access language for many types of databases, including Oracle. True or False?

options.why_false: SQL is the ANSI standard language for relational database management systems, used by Oracle, SQL Server, MySQL, etc.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true? (Choose all correct answers)

options.text: SQL is an ANSI-compliant, nonprocedural, fourth-generation programming language.
PL/SQL is an ANSI-compliant, procedural programming language.
options.why_false: PL/SQL is proprietary to Oracle, not an ANSI standard language like SQL.

options.text: PL/SQL is an Oracle proprietary, procedural, third-generation programming language.
PL/SQL is an Oracle proprietary, procedural, fourth-generation programming language.
options.why_false: PL/SQL is classified as a 3GL (Third-Generation Language) because it introduces procedural constructs, whereas 4GLs are typically declarative.

questions.question: What are the characteristics of a PL/SQL stored subprogram? (Choose two.)

options.text: Can be invoked at any time

options.why_false: By definition, 'stored' subprograms are stored inside the database data dictionary.

options.text: Do not exist after they are executed
options.why_false: Stored subprograms persist in the database until explicitly dropped; they do not disappear after execution.

questions.question: Which sections of a PL/SQL block are optional?

options.why_false: The Executable section (BEGIN...END) is the only mandatory part of a PL/SQL block.
While Exception is optional, the Declaration section is also optional.
The Executable section is mandatory.

questions.question: Which PL/SQL block type must return a value?

options.why_false: Anonymous blocks cannot return values directly to a calling environment in the same way functions do.
A package is a container for procedures and functions; the package itself does not return a value.
Procedures perform actions and can use OUT parameters, but they are not defined to 'return a value' via a RETURN clause like functions.

questions.question: What kind of block is defined by the following PL/SQL code? BEGIN DBMS_OUTPUT.PUT_LINE('My first quiz'); END;

options.why_false: A function must start with the keyword 'CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION' and must return a value.
Subroutine is a generic term; in PL/SQL specific terminology, this unnamed block is an anonymous block.
A procedure is a named block stored in the database (CREATE PROCEDURE). This code has no name.

questions.question: How can you display results to check that a PL/SQL block is working correctly?

options.text: Write a C or Java program to display the results
options.why_false: This is overly complex and unnecessary for simple debugging or display.

options.text: You don't need to do anything, the results will display automatically.
options.why_false: PL/SQL does not output to the screen by default; you must explicitly request output.
The Exception section is for handling errors, not for displaying standard output.

questions.question: Which statement most closely describes 'data type'?

options.text: It is used to test if errors have occurred.
options.why_false: Error testing is handled by Exceptions or conditional logic, not data types.

options.text: It allows different kinds of data to be stored in a single variable.
options.why_false: A data type generally restricts a variable to a specific kind of data (scalar), though composite types exist, the primary definition is about constraints and format.

options.text: It specifies a storage format, constraints, and a valid range of values for a variable.
It is the value of a variable.
options.why_false: The data type defines *what kind* of value can be held, it is not the value itself.

questions.question: Which of the following is a composite data type?

options.why_false: VARCHAR2 is a scalar data type (holds a single value).
CLOB (Character Large Object) is a LOB data type, generally treated as a scalar reference to large data.
DATE is a scalar data type.

questions.question: Which of the following symbols can be used to enclose a comment in PL/SQL?

options.why_false: This is not valid syntax for comments in PL/SQL.
The correct syntax is slash-star to open and star-slash to close (/* ... */).
Colons are used for bind variables or assignment operators (:=), not comments.

questions.question: Which of the following are PL/SQL lexical units? (Choose two.)

options.why_false: Table columns are database objects, not lexical units of the PL/SQL language parser.
Anonymous blocks are structural code units, made up of lexical units, not lexical units themselves.
SQL Workshop is a tool within Oracle APEX, not a programming language unit.

questions.question: Examine the following code. At Line A, we want to assign a value of 22 to the outer block's variable v_myvar. What code should we write at Line A?

options.why_false: Syntax error: The label format should be just the label name followed by dot notation, without the angle brackets in the reference.
This looks like a function call or array index, which is incorrect syntax for label qualification.
This would assign 22 to the *inner* block's variable because the inner declaration shadows the outer one.

options.text: We cannot reference the outer block's variable because both variables have the same name
options.why_false: You can reference shadowed variables by qualifying them with the block label.

questions.question: Two variables with the same name can be declared in an outer block and an inner block. True or False

options.why_false: Variable shadowing is allowed in PL/SQL; the inner variable simply hides the outer one unless qualified.

questions.question: Which of the following variable declarations does NOT use a number data type?

options.why_false: PLS_INTEGER is a numeric data type.
NUMBER is the standard numeric data type.
BINARY_INTEGER is a numeric data type.

questions.question: When declared using %TYPE, a variable will inherit ____ from the column on which it is based.

options.why_false: Grammatically incorrect filler option.
%TYPE inherits the metadata (type/structure), not the actual data content.

options.text: The data type and size of the column

options.why_false: The variable has its own name defined in the declaration, it does not inherit the column's name.

questions.question: When a variable is defined using the NOT NULL keywords, the variable must contain a value. True or False?

options.why_false: The NOT NULL constraint enforces that the variable cannot be null, implying it must be initialized and maintain a value.

questions.question: Identify which of the following assignment statements are valid. (Choose three.)

options.why_false: String literals must be enclosed in single quotes (e.g., 'Chandra').

questions.question: Using standards for naming conventions is recommended. True or False?

options.why_false: Standards improve code readability, maintainability, and consistency, so they are highly recommended.

questions.question: Which of the following makes PL/SQL code easier to read and maintain?

options.why_false: Case sensitivity strategies differ, but typing *everything* in lowercase doesn't inherently solve readability like comments do.

options.text: Place multiple statements on the same line.
options.why_false: This reduces readability by making code cluttered.

options.text: Use suitable comments in the code.

questions.question: The DECODE function is available in PL/SQL procedural statements. True or False?

options.why_false: Traditionally, DECODE is a SQL function. In PL/SQL procedural blocks (outside of a SQL query), you must use IF-THEN-ELSE or CASE statements instead.

questions.question: Which explicit function is used to convert a character into a number?

options.why_false: TO_CHAR converts numbers or dates *to* characters.
TO_DATE converts characters *to* dates.

questions.question: When you use a function to convert data types in a PL/SQL program, it is called ____ conversion.

options.why_false: Implicit conversion happens automatically by the database engine without a function call.
TO_CHAR is a specific function name, not the name of the general concept.

questions.question: MERGE INTO old_trans ot USING new_trans nt ON (ot.trans_id = nt.trans_id) ...; OLD_TRANS is the source table and NEW_TRANS is the target table. True or false?

options.why_false: In MERGE syntax, the table after 'MERGE INTO' is the Target, and the table after 'USING' is the Source. Here, old_trans is the target.

questions.question: When explicitly inserting a row into a table, the VALUES clause must include a value for every column of the table. True or False?

options.why_false: You can omit columns that have default values or allow NULLs if you specify the column list in the INSERT statement.

questions.question: To modify an existing row in a table, you can use the ____ statement.

options.why_false: ALTER is DDL (Data Definition Language) used to change table structure, not data.
INSERT adds new rows; it does not modify existing ones.
MODIFY is a clause used within ALTER TABLE to change column definitions, not a DML statement for data.

questions.question: The UPDATE statement can be used to update more than one row at a time. True or False?

options.why_false: An UPDATE statement acts on all rows that match the WHERE clause condition, which can be zero, one, or many.

questions.question: Multi-table inserts can be conditional or unconditional. True or False?

options.why_false: Oracle SQL supports INSERT ALL and INSERT FIRST statements, which allow for both conditional (using WHEN clauses) and unconditional multi-table insertions.

questions.question: A DEFAULT value can be specified for a column when the table is created. True or false?

options.why_false: The CREATE TABLE syntax explicitly allows a DEFAULT clause to specify a value to be used when no value is provided during an INSERT.

questions.question: You need to update the area code of employees that live in Atlanta. Evaluate this partial UPDATE statement: UPDATE employee SET area_code = 770. Which of the following should you include in your UPDATE statement to achieve the desired results?

options.why_false: This is invalid syntax for filtering; SET is used to assign new values to columns, not to filter rows.
This is invalid syntax. The UPDATE clause specifies the table name, not a column condition.
This clause is incomplete (missing the WHERE keyword) and 'LIKE' is less precise than '=' when you need to match 'Atlanta' exactly.

questions.question: You need to remove a row from the EMPLOYEES table. Which statement would you use?

options.why_false: INSERT is used to add new rows to a table, not to remove them.
UPDATE modifies existing data within rows but does not remove the rows themselves.
MERGE is used to insert or update data based on a condition, not to delete rows (though DELETE clauses can exist inside a MERGE, it is not the primary command for removal).

questions.question: If the subquery returns one row, how many rows will be deleted from the employees table? DELETE FROM employees WHERE department_id = (SELECT department_id FROM departments WHERE department_name LIKE '%Public%');

options.text: All rows in the employees table of employees who work in the given department will be deleted.

options.why_false: Rows will be deleted if there are employees matching the department ID returned by the subquery.

options.text: One row will be deleted, as the subquery only returns one row.
options.why_false: The subquery determines the value for the WHERE clause (department_id). All employees matching that department_id will be deleted, which could be many.

options.text: All rows in the employees table will be deleted, no matter the department_id.
options.why_false: The WHERE clause restricts the deletion to only those rows matching the specific department_id.

questions.question: Which two commands can be used to modify existing data in a database row?

options.why_false: DELETE removes entire rows; it does not modify specific data values within a row.
SELECT is a query command used to retrieve data, not to modify or write data.

questions.question: The PRODUCTS table contains columns: PROD_ID NUMBER(4), PROD_NAME VARCHAR2(25), PROD_PRICE NUMBER(3). You issue: INSERT INTO products VALUES (null, '6-foot nylon leash', 10); What row data did you add to the table?

options.text: The row was created with the correct data in all three columns.
The row was created with the correct data in two of three columns.
options.why_false: The values provided (null, string, number) match the data types and order of all three table columns, so all three are inserted correctly.

options.text: The row was created completely wrong. No data ended up in the correct columns.
options.why_false: The values strictly follow the positional order of the columns defined in the table, so they land in the correct columns.

options.text: The row was created with the correct data in one of the three columns.
options.why_false: All three values correspond to valid data types for their respective columns, so the insertion is fully correct.

questions.question: DML is an acronym that stands for:

options.why_false: There is no SQL term 'Debit Markup Language'. DML specifically refers to commands like INSERT, UPDATE, and DELETE.
Markup Languages (like HTML/XML) are for formatting/transporting data, whereas SQL DML is for manipulating database records.
This is a nonsensical distractor.

questions.question: To do a logical delete of a column without the performance penalty of rewriting all the table datablocks, you can issue the following command:

options.why_false: DROP COLUMN physically removes data, which can be resource-intensive (rewriting data blocks) for large tables.
MODIFY COLUMN is used to change data types or constraints, not to delete columns.
This is syntactically incorrect as a standalone statement; it must be part of an ALTER TABLE command, and even then, it performs a physical drop.

questions.question: The FLASHBACK TABLE to BEFORE DROP can restore only the table structure, but not its data back to before the table was dropped. True or False?

options.why_false: Flashback Table restores the table and its contents (data) from the recycle bin, not just the structure.

questions.question: To completely get rid of a table, its contents, its structure, AND release the storage space the keyword is:

options.why_false: DELETE only removes rows (data); the table structure and storage allocation remain.
KILL is used to terminate sessions, not to manage database objects.
TRUNCATE removes all rows and releases storage, but the table structure (definition) remains.

questions.question: A column's data type can always be changed from NUMBER to VARCHAR2 but not from VARCHAR2 to NUMBER, provided the table is empty. True or False?

options.why_false: If the table is empty, you can change the column data type in either direction (Number to Varchar2 OR Varchar2 to Number).

questions.question: When you use ALTER TABLE to add a column, the new column:

options.text: Becomes the first column in the table
options.why_false: New columns are appended to the end of the existing column list, not the beginning.

options.text: Will not be created because you cannot add a column after the table is created
options.why_false: ALTER TABLE ADD is the specific command designed solely to add columns to existing tables.

options.text: Can be placed by adding a GROUP BY clause
options.why_false: GROUP BY is a SELECT statement clause for aggregation; it has no function in table definition.

options.text: Becomes the last column in the table

questions.question: You need to truncate the EMPLOYEES table. The EMPLOYEES table is not in your schema. Which privilege must you have to truncate the table?

options.text: The TRUNCATE ANY TABLE system privilege
options.why_false: There is no 'TRUNCATE ANY TABLE' privilege in Oracle; truncate operations on other schemas require DROP ANY TABLE.

options.text: The DROP ANY TABLE system privilege
The CREATE ANY TABLE system privilege
options.why_false: This privilege allows creating tables, not removing data or structures owned by others.

options.text: The ALTER ANY TABLE system privilege
options.why_false: While TRUNCATE is DDL, the ALTER privilege is insufficient; Oracle treats TRUNCATE as a destructive action requiring DROP privileges.

questions.question: The TIMESTAMP data type allows what?

options.text: Time to be stored as an interval of years and months.
options.why_false: This describes the INTERVAL YEAR TO MONTH data type.

options.text: Time to be stored as a date with fractional seconds.
Time to be stored as an interval of days to hours, minutes and seconds.
options.why_false: This describes the INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND data type.
TIMESTAMP does store date with fractional seconds, so the previous option is correct.

questions.question: INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND stores a period of time in terms of days, hours, minutes, and seconds. True or False?

options.why_false: This is the exact definition of the INTERVAL DAY TO SECOND data type.

questions.question: Evaluate this CREATE TABLE statement: CREATE TABLE line_item (line_item_id NUMBER(9), order_id NUMBER(9), product_id NUMBER(9)); You are a member of the SYSDBA role, but are logged in under your own schema. You issue this CREATE TABLE statement. Which statement is true?

options.text: You created the table in the SYSDBA schema.
options.why_false: SYSDBA is a role/privilege set, usually mapping to the SYS schema, but if you are logged in as 'your user', objects are created in your schema unless qualified otherwise.

options.text: You created the table in your schema.
You created the LINE ITEM table in the SYS schema.
options.why_false: You would need to explicitly log in AS SYSDBA or qualify the table as SYS.LINE_ITEM to create it in SYS.

options.text: You created the LINE_ITEM table in the public schema.
options.why_false: There is no 'public schema' for table creation; PUBLIC is a user group for privileges/synonyms.

questions.question: Which statement about table and column names is true?

options.text: Table and column names cannot include special characters.
options.why_false: They can include special characters like $, _, and #, or any character if enclosed in double quotes.

options.text: Table and column names can begin with a letter or a number.
options.why_false: Standard unquoted identifiers must begin with a letter, not a number.

options.text: Table and column names must begin with a letter.
If any character other than letters or numbers is used in a table or column name, the name must be enclosed in double quotation marks.
options.why_false: Characters like underscore (_), dollar sign ($), and pound sign (#) are allowed in unquoted identifiers.

questions.question: It is possible to create a table by using the CREATE TABLE command in conjunction with a subquery. True or False?

options.why_false: CREATE TABLE AS SELECT (CTAS) is a standard SQL feature to create a table based on the result of a subquery.

questions.question: Which clause could you use to ensure that cost values are greater than 1.00?

options.why_false: Syntactically incorrect; it lacks a constraint name or follows an invalid order.
The keyword CHECK must come before the condition, but after the constraint name definition.
This is valid for an anonymous check clause if 'CONSTRAINT name' is omitted, but to name it, you must use 'CONSTRAINT name CHECK'.

questions.question: To automatically delete rows in a child table when a parent record is deleted use:

options.why_false: This sets the foreign key column to NULL rather than deleting the row.
This is not a valid SQL syntax.
ON DELETE CASCADE is the correct option.

questions.question: You need to add a PRIMARY KEY constraint on the EMP_ID column of the EMPLOYEES table. Which ALTER TABLE statement should you use?

options.text: ALTER TABLE employees MODIFY CONSTRAINT PRIMARY KEY (emp_id);
options.why_false: MODIFY CONSTRAINT is used to change properties of an existing constraint, not to add a new Primary Key.

options.text: ALTER TABLE employees ADD CONSTRAINT emp_emp_id_pk PRIMARY KEY(emp_id);
ALTER TABLE employees MODIFY emp_id PRIMARY KEY;
options.why_false: You cannot simply 'MODIFY column PRIMARY KEY' to add a named table constraint; Primary Keys are usually added via ADD CONSTRAINT.

options.text: ALTER TABLE employees ADD CONSTRAINT PRIMARY KEY (emp_id);
options.why_false: When using ADD CONSTRAINT, you must provide a name for the constraint.

questions.question: Evaluate this statement: ALTER TABLE employees ENABLE CONSTRAINT emp_id_pk; For which task would you issue this statement?

options.text: To add a new constraint to the EMPLOYEES table
options.why_false: This syntax enables an existing constraint; it does not define or add a new one.

options.text: To activate a new constraint while preventing the creation of a PRIMARY KEY index
options.why_false: Enabling a PK constraint typically ensures an index exists or creates one; it does not inherently prevent index creation.

options.text: To disable an existing constraint on the EMPLOYEES table
options.why_false: The keyword used is ENABLE, not DISABLE.

options.text: To activate the previously disabled constraint on the EMPLOYEE_ID column while creating a PRIMARY KEY index

questions.question: Which of the following is not a valid Oracle constraint type?

options.why_false: This is a fundamental constraint type.
This is a valid constraint type.
This is a valid constraint type.
The correct term is FOREIGN KEY; EXTERNAL KEY is not a valid Oracle SQL term.

questions.question: Which two statements about NOT NULL constraints are true?

options.text: A NOT NULL constraint can be defined at either the table or column level.
options.why_false: NOT NULL constraints can generally only be defined at the column level (inline), not at the table level.

options.text: You CANNOT add a NOT NULL constraint to an existing column using the ALTER TABLE ADD CONSTRAINT statement.
Columns with a NOT NULL constraint can contain null values by default.
options.why_false: NOT NULL specifically prohibits null values.

options.text: The NOT NULL constraint requires that every value in a column be unique.
options.why_false: Uniqueness is enforced by the UNIQUE constraint, not NOT NULL.

options.text: The Oracle Server creates a name for an unnamed NOT NULL constraint.

questions.question: A column defined as NOT NULL can have a DEFAULT value of NULL. True or False?

options.why_false: While syntactically you might attempt it, logically a NOT NULL column cannot accept NULL as a value, so a default of NULL would cause insert failures if relied upon.

questions.question: Which of the following keywords cannot be used when creating a view?

options.why_false: HAVING is valid in the SELECT definition of a view.
WHERE is valid in the SELECT definition of a view.
ORDER BY is valid in a view definition (though strictly speaking, views are unordered sets, Oracle allows the syntax).

options.text: They are all valid keywords when creating views.

questions.question: Which option would you use to modify a view rather than dropping it and recreating it?

options.why_false: NOFORCE controls whether the base tables must exist at creation time; it does not handle modification.
This is used for granting privileges, not defining views.
FORCE allows creating a view even if the base table doesn't exist, but it doesn't replace an existing view definition.

questions.question: In order to query a database using a view, which of the following statements applies?

options.why_false: There is no special 'VIEW SELECT' syntax; you use standard SELECT.

options.text: The tables you are selecting from can be empty, yet the view still returns the original data from those tables.
options.why_false: A view is a stored query; if the underlying tables are empty, the view returns no data.

options.text: You can retrieve data from a view as you would from any table.
You can never see all the rows in the table through the view.
options.why_false: A view can be defined as 'SELECT * FROM table', which would show all rows.

questions.question: You want to create a view based on the SALESREP table... You want Sales employees to be able to update the SALESREP table through the view... What should not be specified in your CREATE VIEW statement?

options.why_false: AS is mandatory syntax for defining a view.
Views with WHERE clauses are often updatable.
IN is allowed in the WHERE clause of an updatable view.

questions.question: When you drop a view, the data it contains is also deleted. True or False?

options.why_false: A view does not store data itself; it is a window to the base tables. Dropping the view deletes the definition, not the underlying data.

questions.question: Which of the following is TRUE regarding simple views?

options.text: Simple views can be used to perform DML operations.
Simple views contain functions or groups of data.
options.why_false: Views containing functions or grouping are considered 'Complex Views', not simple ones.

options.text: Simple views are not stored in the Data Dictionary.
options.why_false: All view definitions are stored in the Data Dictionary.

options.text: Simple views retrieve data from many tables, so they typically contain joins.
options.why_false: Simple views typically retrieve data from a single table without joins.

questions.question: Which of the following DML operations is not allowed when using a Simple View created with read only?

options.why_false: INSERT is indeed not allowed, but the question asks what is not allowed and offers 'All of the above' which covers this.
UPDATE is not allowed, covered by 'All of the above'.
DELETE is not allowed, covered by 'All of the above'.

questions.question: What is the purpose of including the WITH CHECK OPTION clause when creating a view?

options.text: To insure that no rows are updated through the view that would prevent those rows from being returned by the view in the future.
To make sure that the parent table(s) actually exist
options.why_false: Existence of tables is checked at creation time regardless of this option (unless FORCE is used).

options.text: To make sure that data is not duplicated in the view
options.why_false: This would be the job of a UNIQUE constraint on the table, not a view option.

options.text: To keep views form being queried by unauthorized persons
options.why_false: Security is handled by GRANT privileges, not the CHECK OPTION.

questions.question: Which statement about an index is true?

options.text: An index can only be created on a single table column.
options.why_false: Indexes can be created on multiple columns (composite indexes).

options.text: An index created on multiple columns is called a composite or concatenated index.
Creating an index reorders the data in the underlying table.
options.why_false: Indexes are separate structures; they do not physically reorder the table heap data (except for Index-Organized Tables, but that's a specific table type).

options.text: Creating an index will always improve query performance.
options.why_false: Indexes can degrade performance on DML (inserts/updates) and may not be used if the query selectivity is poor.

questions.question: In SQL what is a synonym?

options.text: A table with the same name as another view
options.why_false: A synonym is an alias, not a separate table.

options.text: A different name for a table, view, or other database object
A table that must be qualified with a username
options.why_false: This describes schema qualification, not the definition of a synonym.

options.text: A table with the same number of columns as another table
options.why_false: This implies structure similarity, unrelated to the concept of synonyms.

questions.question: What is the correct syntax for creating an index?

options.why_false: The name of the index must follow 'CREATE INDEX', not precede it.
An index name is required in the standard CREATE INDEX syntax.

options.text: CREATE OR REPLACE INDEX index_name ON table_name(column_name);
options.why_false: Standard SQL does not support 'OR REPLACE' for indexes; you must drop and recreate.

questions.question: When creating a sequence, which keyword or option specifies the minimum sequence value?

options.why_false: This specifies the maximum value.
This specifies whether the sequence should restart after reaching the limit.
This specifies that there is no maximum limit (other than system limits).

questions.question: Sequences can be used to: (Choose three)

options.text: Ensure primary key values will be unique and consecutive
options.why_false: Sequences guarantee uniqueness but not consecutiveness (gaps can occur due to rollbacks or caching).

options.text: Ensure primary key values will be unique even though gaps may exist
Set a fixed interval between successively generated numbers.
Generate a range of numbers and optionally cycle through them again
Guarantee that no primary key values are unused
options.why_false: Sequences do not guarantee no gaps/unused values.

questions.question: Evaluate this CREATE SEQUENCE statement: CREATE SEQUENCE order_id_seq NOCYCLE NOCACHE; Which statement is true?

options.text: The sequence preallocates values and retains them in memory.
options.why_false: The NOCACHE option explicitly prevents preallocation/caching.

questions.question: Examine the following code: CREATE PROCEDURE parent IS BEGIN child1; child2; EXCEPTION WHEN NO_DATA_FOUND THEN NULL; END parent; Neither CHILD1 nor CHILD2 has an exception handler. When PARENT is invoked, CHILD1 raises a NO_DATA_FOUND exception. What happens next?

options.text: CHILD1 ends abruptly, PARENT handles the exception, and then CHILD2 executes.
options.why false: Execution in the block (PARENT) stops immediately when the exception bubbles up; CHILD2 is skipped.

options.text: CHILD1 ends abruptly; PARENT handles the exception and then ends; CHILD2 does not execute.
CHILD1 ends abruptly; PARENT also ends abruptly and returns an unhandled exception.
options.why false: PARENT has an explicit handler for NO_DATA_FOUND, so it does not end abruptly.

options.text: PARENT does not compile because you cannot use NULL; in an exception handler.
options.why false: Using NULL; is valid syntax for an exception handler that does nothing.

options.text: PARENT handles the exception, and then CHILD1 continues to execute.
options.why false: Once CHILD1 raises an exception, its execution is terminated; it cannot 'continue'.

questions.question: The following code shows the dependencies between three procedures: [Parent calls Child1 and Child2]. You now try to execute: DROP PROCEDURE child2; What happens?

options.text: You cannot drop CHILD2 because PARENT is dependent on it.
options.why false: Oracle allows dropping objects that others depend on, though it invalidates the dependents.

options.text: CHILD2 is dropped successfully. PARENT is marked INVALID, but CHILD1 is still valid.
CHILD2 is dropped successfully. PARENT and CHILD1 are both marked INVALID.
options.why false: CHILD1 is independent of CHILD2 and PARENT (in terms of compilation), so it remains valid.

options.text: The database automatically drops CHILD1 as well.
options.why false: Dropping one procedure does not cascade delete other referenced procedures.

options.text: The database automatically drops PARENT as well.
options.why false: Dropping a dependency invalidates the parent but does not drop it.

questions.question: User BOB is not a database administrator. BOB wants to see the names of all the tables in his schema, as well as all the tables in other users' schemas which he has privileges to use. Which Data Dictionary view would BOB query to do this?

options.why false: ALL_TABLES is the correct answer provided in the list.
DBA_TABLES is usually restricted to administrators and shows all tables in the database.
This shows column information, not a list of tables, and defaults to the user's schema.
USER_TABLES shows only tables owned by the user, not accessible tables owned by others.

questions.question: Which of the following will tell you how many functions you own?

options.why false: This counts all objects (tables, indexes, etc.), not just functions.
This counts procedures and functions (and packages in some versions), not strictly functions alone.
There is no standard data dictionary view named USER_FUNCTIONS.

options.text: SELECT COUNT(*) FROM USER_OBJECTS WHERE OBJECT_TYPE='FUNCTION';

options.why false: There is no column named 'FUNCTIONS' in USER_OBJECTS.

questions.question: USERB creates a function called SEL_PROC which includes the statement: SELECT ... FROM usera.employees ...; USERC needs to execute UserB's procedure. What privileges are needed for this to work correctly? (Choose two.)

options.why false: EXECUTE is granted on specific objects (like the procedure), not on the user schema itself.
UserA owns the data but does not need execute rights on the procedure referencing it.
With Definer's Rights (default), UserC relies on UserB's privileges, not their own, to access the data.

questions.question: User SVETLANA creates a view called EMP_VIEW that is based on a SELECT from her EMPLOYEES table. Svetlana now wants user PHIL to be able to query the view. What is the smallest set of object privileges that Svetlana must grant to Phil?

options.why false: EXECUTE is for procedures/functions, not views.

options.text: SELECT on EMP_VIEW and REFERENCES on EMPLOYEES
options.why false: Phil does not need REFERENCES on the underlying table to query the view.

options.text: SELECT on EMP_VIEW and SELECT on EMPLOYEES
options.why false: Phil does not need direct SELECT access to the underlying EMPLOYEES table; the view handles the access rights.
